title: JAIIB IE&IFS Mock – P1 Module A (Set p1ma1)

questions.question: According to the Angus Maddison database cited in the capsule, what was the combined share of India and China in world GDP around 1000 AD (PPP, 1990 dollars)?
questions.explanation: The capsule notes that in 1000 AD, India and China together contributed 50.5% of global GDP in PPP terms computed in 1990 dollars.

questions.question: As per the capsule, India’s share of world output around 1820 fell to which figure?
questions.explanation: By 1820, India’s share had plummeted to 16.1% due to colonial economic changes.

questions.question: In 2021, India’s share of global GDP and PPP ranking are stated as:
questions.explanation: The capsule lists 7.3% of global GDP in 2021 and India’s PPP rank as #3 globally.

questions.question: Which two hubs structure the NITI Aayog, as per the document?
options: Team India Hub and Knowledge & Innovation Hub
questions.explanation: NITI Aayog is organised around the Team India Hub and the Knowledge & Innovation Hub.

questions.question: Who chairs the NITI Aayog?
questions.explanation: The capsule clearly states: Chairman — Prime Minister.

questions.question: Which body calculates the Index of Industrial Production (IIP) and the Index of Core Industries (ICI)?
options: Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade
questions.explanation: The capsule specifies that NSO calculates the IIP and also the ICI.

questions.question: Identify the correct list of Eight Core Industries as given in the capsule.
options: Refinery Products, Electricity, Steel, Coal, Crude Oil, Natural Gas, Cement, Fertilisers
Automobiles, Textiles, Refinery Products, Electricity, Steel, Coal, Cement, Fertilisers
Electricity, Steel, Coal, Crude Oil, Natural Gas, Cement, Fertilisers, Textiles
Refinery Products, Steel, Coal, Crude Oil, Natural Gas, Cement, Fertilisers, Automobiles
questions.explanation: The eight are: Refinery Products; Electricity; Steel; Coal; Crude Oil; Natural Gas; Cement; Fertilisers.

questions.question: What does GVA (Gross Value Added) measure, as defined in the capsule?
options: Contribution of each sector before taxes/subsidies
questions.explanation: GVA measures the contribution of each sector to the economy before accounting for taxes/subsidies.

questions.question: Which sector’s proportion in India’s economy increased from ~33% in 1950 to ~53% by 2021‑22, as per the capsule?
questions.explanation: The services sector’s share rose from ~33% to ~53% over the period noted.

questions.question: Which is NOT categorised as a service sub‑sector in the capsule’s list?
questions.explanation: Mining and quarrying are industrial; the others are service sub‑sectors listed in the capsule.

questions.question: Under the 2020 revised PSL categories, which of the following was specifically added?
questions.explanation: The capsule highlights Start‑ups (≤ ₹50 crore) as an addition in the 2020 PSL update.

questions.question: Standard capsule targets for PSL (as % of ANBC/CEOBE) are noted as a quick pattern to remember. Which combination matches that mnemonic?
questions.explanation: For capsule revision: 40% overall; 18% Agriculture; ~7.5% often used for micro‑enterprises (bank‑specific circulars may vary).

questions.question: As per the new MSME definition (26 June 2020), the thresholds for a ‘Small’ enterprise are:
questions.explanation: Small: Investment ≤ ₹10 crore; Turnover ≤ ₹50 crore (uniform for manufacturing/services).

questions.question: MSME registration is done through which portal as per the capsule?
questions.explanation: Registration is via the Udyam Portal; self‑declaration and paperless.

questions.question: Under ECLGS mentioned in the capsule, the guaranteed collateral‑free support was up to:
questions.explanation: ECLGS: ₹3 lakh crore collateral‑free support (COVID relief) via MLIs.

questions.question: CGTMSE provides collateral‑free loans up to what limit, as per the capsule?
questions.explanation: CGTMSE: collateral‑free loans up to ₹1 crore (MoMSME & SIDBI).

questions.question: The Production Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme outlay and incentive range stated are:
options: ₹ 1.97 lakh crore; incentives 4–6% over base year for 4–6 years
questions.explanation: PLI: ₹1.97 lakh crore across 13 sectors; 4–6% incentives over the base year for 4–6 years.

questions.question: Which description best matches the ‘Organised’ vs ‘Unorganised’ sector comparison in the capsule?
options: Organised: registered, monthly pay with benefits; Unorganised: not registered, daily wages; workforce share ≈ 7% vs 93%
Organised: not registered, daily wages; Unorganised: registered, monthly pay; workforce share ≈ 93% vs 7%
Both are registered but differ only in PF coverage; workforce share ≈ 50% each
Organised: always public sector; Unorganised: always private sector; workforce share ≈ 25% vs 75%
questions.explanation: The capsule table shows Organised registered with monthly pay/benefits; Unorganised not registered with daily wages; workforce ≈ 7% vs 93%.

questions.question: Which set correctly pairs the five economic sectors listed in the capsule?
questions.explanation: The capsule lists the five‑fold sectoral classification including Quaternary and Quinary.

questions.question: Which of the following is listed among ‘Sunrise Sectors’ in the capsule?
questions.explanation: Sunrise sectors include Green Energy, FinTech/IT, Electronics, Pharma, Automobiles, Healthcare, Infrastructure, Retail, Processing.

questions.question: Which growth characterisation is used for 1951–1980 in the capsule?
questions.explanation: 1951–80 is described as the ‘Hindu Rate of Growth’ at around 3.5%.

questions.question: The IIP in the capsule uses which base year?
questions.explanation: The capsule mentions IIP with base 2011–12.

questions.question: Which pair of years does the capsule cite as instances of negative per‑capita income growth during the planning era?
questions.explanation: The capsule notes negative per‑capita income growth in 1971–72 and 1991–92.

questions.question: Which of the following combinations matches the indicative GDP composition cited for 2020–21?
questions.explanation: For 2020–21, the capsule’s indicative shares are Services ~60.9%, Industry ~19.8%, Primary ~20.1%.

questions.question: Which statement about India’s economic structure at independence and its evolution is consistent with the capsule?
options: India began as an industrial economy and shifted to agriculture later
India was dominated by the primary sector at independence; the shares of industry and services rose over time
Services share fell from 33% to 20% after independence
Agriculture’s share rose steadily after independence due to planned targets
questions.explanation: The capsule notes a primary‑sector‑dominated economy at independence, with industry and services increasing their shares over time.
